lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write sentences (e.g., “She plays badminton.”) clearly and accurately in the correct space.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Write: “She plays badminton.” Say the sentence. Students copy it and write one more using a new sport or instrument.
stretchStrategies: Students write 2–3 original sentences using the target language (“He plays… / She doesn’t play…”). Then, they read them without revealing the answers, and classmates must guess true or false, prompting peer correction and language reflection.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to spoken descriptions and select the correct instruments and sports.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Say: “He plays the flute. She plays volleyball.” Students point to the matching image or circle the correct answer in SB.
stretchStrategies: Students write 2–3 original sentences using the target language (“He plays… / She doesn’t play…”). Then, they read them without revealing the answers, and classmates must guess true or false, prompting peer correction and language reflection.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can work together politely and take turns in a competitive game.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Competition) Team game: One student describes (e.g., “He plays the ___”). Others race to choose the right flashcard and answer.
stretchStrategies: Students write 2–3 original sentences using the target language (“He plays… / She doesn’t play…”). Then, they read them without revealing the answers, and classmates must guess true or false, prompting peer correction and language reflection.

items: Bạn có thích ăn bánh mì không? >> you like eat bread? [do you like to eat bánh mì?]
Con không thích >> I no/not like [I don't like]
Playground words tend to be long and phonetically difficult (slide, see-saw, swings, climbing frame)
Some sports not well known in VN (baseball, cricket, rugby, paragliding, water skiing)
A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.
